description: Unclear. Perhaps from Middle English slugge, from Old Norse slókr (“lazy fellow”). See also Swedish sloka (“to slouch, wilt”), related to Swedish slak (“slack, soft and flexible”) and Latin laxus (“loose, slack”).

entries.meaning: A hanging down of the head; a drooping posture; a limp appearance
examples: He sat with an unenthusiastic slouch.

entries.meaning: Any depression or hanging down, as of a hat brim.
examples: The plant hung in a permanent slouch.

entries.meaning: Someone who is slow to act.

verbs.description: slouch (third-person singular simple present slouches, present participle slouching, simple past and past participle slouched)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To hang or droop; to adopt a limp posture
examples: Do not slouch when playing a flute.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To walk in a clumsy, lazy manner.
examples: I slouched to the fridge to see if there was anything to eat.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to hang down or droop; to depress.
